nodes.title: (233) Zhu gYung drung kun grags gling

nodes.body: The temple was built in the late 1980s by a certain gYung drung tshul khrims who, although not himself of the Zhu lineage, had connections with that family - hence the name of the temple. He himself is said to be the proprietor of a photo-studio in Gangtok.
nodes.title: 3. History

nodes.body: There is one monk, name rNam rgyal, a product of sMan ri Monastery (No.231) in Dolanji, who is taking care of the teaching at the temple.
nodes.title: 4. Hierarchical system

nodes.body: There are about a dozen young monks from local families.
nodes.title: 5. Number of monks/ priests

nodes.body: Very limited exchange for the present, although the temple does receive visits from colleagues of rNam rgyal from Dolanji.
nodes.title: 7. Personnel and educational exchange of monks between monasteries

nodes.body: Mainly modern Indian reprints of Bonpo works
nodes.title: 11. Books and manuscripts kept by the monastery

nodes.body: The temple is supported by donations from the families of the young monks.
nodes.title: 12. Economic circumstances of temple

nodes.body: The villagers in the vicinity of the temple are mainly sedentary farmers.
nodes.title: 14. Economic occupation of the local population
